hints_html: The slope of a line is the ratio of rise over run.
hints_latex: The slope of a line is the ratio of rise over run.
hints_raw: The slope of a line is the ratio of rise over run.
question: 7 (b)
sols_html:
We have two points:

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle (4, -12) \qquad (a, a^2-6a)\end{aligned}\]

So the slope, m, of the line going through these two points is the ratio of rise (change in the y-coordinates) over run (change in the x-coordinates):

\[\begin{aligned} m = \frac{(-12) - (a^2-6a)}{4-a} = -\frac{a^2-6a+12}{4-a}\end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
We have two points:
:<math>\displaystyle
(4, -12) \qquad (a, a^2-6a)
</math>

So the slope, ''m'', of the line going through these two points is the ratio of rise (change in the y-coordinates) over run (change in the x-coordinates): 
:<math>
m = \frac{(-12) - (a^2-6a)}{4-a} = -\frac{a^2-6a+12}{4-a}
</math>
statement_html:
Let \(f(x)\) = x2 - 6x and let P be the point (4, -12).

b) Find the slope of the line between P and a point (a, a2 - 6a) on the curve y = \(f(x)\).
statement_latex:
Let $f(x)$ = \emph{x}\textsuperscript{2} - 6\emph{x} and let
\emph{P} be the point (4, -12).

b) Find the slope of the line between \emph{P} and a point (\emph{a},
\emph{a}\textsuperscript{2} - 6\emph{a}) on the curve \emph{y} =
$f(x)$.
statement_raw:
Let &fnof;(''x'') = ''x''<sup>2</sup> - 6''x'' and let ''P'' be the point (4, -12).  

b) Find the slope of the line between ''P'' and a point (''a'', ''a''<sup>2</sup> - 6''a'') on the curve ''y'' = &fnof;(''x'').
